review.title: Joint Image-Text News Topic Detection and Tracking with And-Or Graph Representation
review.abstract: In this paper, we aim to develop a method for automatically detecting and tracking topics in broadcast news. We present a hierarchical And-Or graph (AOG) to jointly represent the latent structure of both texts and visuals. The AOG embeds a context sensitive grammar that can describe the hierarchical composition of news topics by semantic elements about people involved, related places and what happened, and model contextual relationships between elements in the hierarchy. We detect news topics through a cluster sampling process which groups stories about closely related events. Swendsen-Wang Cuts (SWC), an effective cluster sampling algorithm, is adopted for traversing the solution space and obtaining optimal clustering solutions by maximizing a Bayesian posterior probability. Topics are tracked to deal with the continuously updated news streams. We generate topic trajectories to show how topics emerge, evolve and disappear over time. The experimental results show that our method can explicitly describe the textual and visual data in news videos and produce meaningful topic trajectories. Our method achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods on both a public dataset Reuters-21578 and a self-collected dataset named UCLA Broadcast News Dataset.

sections.heading: 1.2.2 Task: Detecting and Tracking News Topics
sections.text: In the massive and continuously updated news data, each news topic evolves over time. We aim to identify topics within short periods of time and generate long-term news histories. Therefore, we can show both detailed descriptions of each topic over different periods of time, as well as how each topic evolves over time. It also helps to avoid the heavy computation that occurs by periodically identifying topics using the entire updated news collection. To identify topics, we group stories that work on the same topics. The proposed AOG explicitly describes components of different topics, so we can effectively group related stories and generatemeaningful topics based on the AOG. We solve the grouping problem by clustering methods by maximizing a downstream probability. An efficient cluster sampling algorithm introduced in image segmentation, i.e. SwendsenWang Cuts (SWC) [17], shows temporary topics.

sections.heading: 1.3 Summary of Contributions
sections.text: This paper contains the following contributions: • We have proposed a common image-text composition for a common text theme, based on And-Or diagrams that make better use of multimodal data and provide interpretations with an appropriate amount of detail compared to single-modal methods and other representations [1], [3], [6], [8], [18], [19]. • We solve the issue of topic recognition with the clustering sampling method Swendsen-Wang Cuts, which performs better than commonly used greedy algorithms [3], [6], [8], [20]. • We identify and track topics simultaneously over time by generating both topic summaries in different time periods and long-term themes. The results show how topics evolve over time and provide useful data for further media analysis, with 4 topics hardly being fulfilled by traditional recognition methods. • We have compiled a message database for a common text-theme-picture-theme.

sections.heading: 2 RELATED WORK
sections.text: Our work focuses on the following four lines of research: (1) Topic Modeling, (2) Topic Clustering, (3) Topic Tracking and (4) News Collecting and Delivery Systems.

sections.heading: 2.1 Topic Modeling
sections.text: Among the large number of methods of topic modeling, probabilistic topic models [21], [2] and their extensions [23], [24], [25], [4], [26], [27] are effectively used to identify and analyze latent topics. Although these methods are effective in general topic modeling, they can hardly perform well in the news field by using only the sack-of-words representation (BoW), which is mathematically efficient but ignores the compositional structures that are important for news analysis. News stories are generally driven by events, so information from aspects such as "who," "where" and "what" is crucial for summarizing these stories and generating significant news topics. Newman et al. [28] considered these aspects, but included them as a whole. Li et al. [29] used information from the above aspects in their image representation assumes that they are generally only relevant to actual data.

sections.heading: 2.2 Topic Clustering
sections.text: They assume that every news story talks about a news event that corresponds to a topic. A large number of methods for topic capture in topic capture and tracking (TDT) research [15] (e.g. [1], [34]) use cluster methods to detect news topics that collect stories on the same topic. Traditional cluster methods [5] can also be used for topic capture, but most of these methods are one-modular and mainly focus on the text domain. Multimodal topic cluster methods have been proposed by taking both texts and visualizations into account. In most of these methods, texts are presented with the BoW representation [8], [36], [7]. For visual representation, some methods are presented using the color histograms of the keyframes [8].

sections.heading: 2.3 Topic Tracking
sections.text: The traditional topic-tracking problem in TDT [15], [1] is defined as the process of finding related additional stories for some topics that have already been learned. Many methods have been proposed to solve this problem, such as those in [15], [37], [38]. However, deciding on the topic of each new story based on the topics learned previously can take a long time in a large data set. Furthermore, they can hardly deal with the newly emerging topics. In the community of probability models, some models also contain time information, such as the Dynamic Topic Model (DTM) [4], which can model theme development over time. However, the topics are assumed to exist over the entire period, which is not usually true in news broadcasts. It also leads to extensive calculations for constantly updated new flows. Instead of using the previous two methods, we opt to link the news topics identified in different time periods and follow the themes over time.

sections.heading: 2.4 News Gathering and Delivering System
sections.text: In [41], [42] Chang et al. introduced a system called News Rover to integrate multimodal news sources. News topics are collected from sources such as Google News and organized into a hierarchical topic structure, and news stories are then assigned to those topics. Another personalized news video system, Own News [43], [44], can aggregate news videos from multiple sources, matching the extracted news stories with online news articles to obtain the corresponding news categories. In this essay, we recognize and track news topics in a completely unsupervised manner by jointly modelling texts and images to support media analysis in social and political science (e.g. the two case studies mentioned in Section 1.1).

sections.heading: 4 TOPIC DETECTION
sections.text: In this section we present our formulation of the topic recognition problem and the algorithm for optimizing a Bavarian posterior probability for the topic recognition problem.

sections.heading: 4.1 Problem Formulation
sections.text: With hierarchical AOG topic representation, our goal of topic recognition is to bundle news stories that describe the same topics and obtain the AOG model parameters for the topics. We present this cluster problem as a graph distribution problem in which news stories are divided into coherent groups (max.) as vertices in the neighborhood diagram. We show an example of the neighborhood diagram in Fig. 6. Edges in the neighborhood diagram are associated with certain weights that correspond to related similarities. Partitions can be achieved by dividing the vertices into groups with specific properties and also keeping the number of edges between separated components small. Graph partitioning can help detect the news topic because even when news stories from a topic evolve over time and drive the topic, they can still be summarized by linking contiguous stories with minor changes and similar sub-ranges.

So it can solve the coupling problem of the Gibbs sampler components (which move a single vertex label) by jumping quickly between local minima. sections.heading: 5 TOPIC TRACKING
sections.text: In this section, we describe our method of tracking a variable number of topics that are detected in certain continuous periods of time. [15] Unlike the traditional topic tracking problem [15], where the topic to be followed is provided and the task is to determine whether new stories belong to the given topic, we instead link all captured topics in different periods of time to form topic paths over time. Then, based on the trajectories, we can perform further analyses, such as the analysis of sentiment / emotion topics that evolve with the topic. We divide the entire news data collection into several subcollections that consist of news stories in different periods of time. Topic collection is performed separately within each subcollection. sections.heading: 6.1 Datasets
sections.text: Two sets of data are used in our experiment: 1) Reuters-21578. Reuters-21578 dataset4 is a publicly available collection of news from Reuters newswire. It is widely used to evaluate clustering and classification methods.The dataset contains 21,758 stories belonging to 135 clusters / categories, the clusters / categories are commented manually, only textual information is in the dataset.2) UCLA Broadcast News Dataset. We collected a multimedia news dataset from UCLA Library Broadcast NewsScape. Five U.S. networks are included in the dataset: CNN, MSNBC, FOX, ABC, and CBS. It contains 379 news videos broadcast between June 1, 2013 and June 14, 2013. The total length of the videos is approximately 362 hours. Several programs from each news network are included in the dataset, such as "CNN Newsroom," "MSNBC," MSNBC Live News, "FOX News" ABC News "EZ.

sections.heading: 6.2 Implementation Details
sections.text: Implementation details (including pre-processing) for the two datasets used in the experiment are described below: 1) Reuters-21578: In the experiment, stories with multiple cluster labels are discarded and only those from the largest 10 clusters are selected for the remaining stories. 2) UCLA Broadcast News Dataset: We use text from both video frames and closed captions (CC); text extraction on video frames is performed using optical character recognition (OCR) based on Google OCR engine Tesseract; and the results are further refined with spatio-temporal relationships between frames.

sections.heading: 6.3 Experiment I: Topic Detection
sections.text: In this experiment, we conduct topic recognition experiments on both the Reuters-21578 dataset and the UCLA Broadcast News Dataset.

sections.heading: 6.3.1 Results on Reuters-21578
sections.text: On Reuters-21578 we follow the evaluation protocol in [6], [53]. Two metrics are then used to evaluate cluster performance, i.e. accuracy and normalized mutual information. To calculate the accuracy, the obtained clusters are assigned to the topic of the basic truth clusters in the dataset. Accuracy is then defined as the percentage of documents that have the correct cluster identification after mapping. Mutual information measurement measures the interdependence of cluster assignments and the obtained cluster assignments for the documents. Normalized mutual information is a standardized version of this unit of measurement. Further details of the definitions of these two metrics can be found in [53]. Baseline methods are included in comparison.

sections.heading: 6.3.2 Results on UCLA Broadcast News Dataset
sections.text: We perform both qualitative and quantitative evaluations of our topic detection method on the UCLA Broadcast News Dataset. In the qualitative experiment, we show the topics covered by our method. In the quantitative experiment, we compare the detection performance of our method with other algorithms. We perform the common image-text-theme detection across the whole dataset, i.e. the cluster numbers for the grouping of faces and object patches in Section 3 are set as textual and visual information from all news stories in the dataset. Parameter Settings in Eq. 13 is set as α = 10. The cluster numbers for the grouping of faces and object patches in Section 3 are set as 1, 000 and 500 respectively. We also delete clusters with a small number of patches. The remaining cluster numbers for face and object are we as 708 and 1, 316 respectively.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have introduced a common image-text method for topic identification and tracking. We use the And-Or graph as a structured representation of topics that jointly models the image and text portions of topics. We identify topics using the SWC-based cluster sampling method. Topics are also tracked over time to cope with the continuous updates of news flows. Qualitative and quantitative evaluation results show both the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method for topic identification and tracking. In the future, we intend to expand our study to the problem of media analysis for social and political science research. Based on our topic recognition and tracking results, we can analyze how media tends to be for different topics, what is the agenda-setting pattern, what are the causal relationships between topics, etc.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we aim to develop a method for automatically detecting and tracking topics in broadcast news. We present a hierarchical And-Or graph (AOG) to jointly represent the latent structure of both texts and visuals. The AOG embeds a context sensitive grammar that can describe the hierarchical composition of news topics by semantic elements about people involved, related places and what happened, and model contextual relationships between elements in the hierarchy. We detect news topics through a cluster sampling process which groups stories about closely related events. Swendsen-Wang Cuts (SWC), an effective cluster sampling algorithm, is adopted for traversing the solution space and obtaining optimal clustering solutions by maximizing a Bayesian posterior probability. Topics are tracked to deal with the continuously updated news streams. We generate topic trajectories to show how topics emerge, evolve and disappear over time. The experimental results show that our method can explicitly describe the textual and visual data in news videos and produce meaningful topic trajectories. Our method achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods on both a public dataset Reuters-21578 and a self-collected dataset named UCLA Broadcast News Dataset.
